Title: Bio-Dead

reviewText: BIO-DEAD is a real dead film, shot in an office like many of us have or do work in, some of the "Dead" characters who all have japanese horror shakes actually remind me of real live people who I have dealt with in offices. My opinion of "BIO-DEAD" is very low in fact I highly recommend filing it in file 13. Once in more than enough. Do not buy this movie, it ain't bad that would be too nice a thing to say about it.
Title: Bio-Dead

reviewText: Should be re-titled, "BIO-CRAP"!YES... I was stupid enough to pay $10 for this one!!!  Save your time and money. Basically, below low budget film about 4 guys wondering around in an abandoned office building for almost an hour and a half.... like I said.... BORING!!!!!!!  I'm sure the maker of this piece of crap thought it would be scary to have a bald blue skin guy show up here and there with a jittery shaking head, like we've seen many, many, many... many times before (like in "Fear.com" and so on...).  Seen it!!  Nothing new here, except more boredom. If you do decide to be unfortunate enough to watch this garbage, keep the remote close by... the Fast Forward button will come in handy.  Recommended viewing time... less than 5 minutes (less than 1 min. is best)!!!!This is one of those ones you wish you could join a class action suit against the maker and all those involved, just to get recovery for time, money, and not to mention pain and suffering!!!!CAN I GET A REFUND???!!!!!
Title: Bio-Dead

reviewText: I had several problems with this movie.First, the entire movie was filmed with a soft focus. I can understand something like that for dream scenes, but not for a while movie.Second, the main characters seemed unable to work at a burger joint let alone as a specialized team searching for survivors in an area contaminated with a deadly toxin. The team leader showed no leadership ability at all. The other three members were completely unable to follow simple orders.Third, the movie made little to no effort to explain what was happening to the team and the ending made no sense. Now some people like movies that leave most of the details to the viewer's imagination--I'm not one of them.Finally, the movie is incredibly slow paced. A lot of screen time is given to scenes that added nothing to what plot there is. In one scene, a character took over two minutes to search a small three stall restroom. Of course in the middle of the scene we were treated to him deliberately peeing all over one of the toilets. That added so much to the plot of the film--NOT!If you enjoy movies like this one, then get the popcorn ready. For those who don't, save your money and your time and give this one a miss.
Title: Bio-Dead

reviewText: In truth, my expectations for the low budget horror endeavor "Bio-Dead" were pretty limited.  I'm happy to report that in almost all ways, the film was much more accomplished than I had anticipated.  Working with a familiar concept, but casting effective actors and utilizing special effects moments with economy, the director has come up with a creepy new twist on the haunted house drama.  Ostensibly set in the near future where a biological agent has wiped out approximately 12 million people, governmental agencies have hired crews to enter the contaminated zone to inventory casualties.  The film charts the unpleasantness that awaits a team of four civilians on just such a detail.  Having limited finances, the director astutely kept things on a small scale with almost all of the action contained within an abandoned building.  Again, although the setting approximates a science fiction feeling (with post-apocalyptic undertones)--at heart, this is most akin to spending the night in a haunted house.The movie begins with an extended sequence where we are introduced to the characters through voice alone.  These scenes, filmed and filtered entirely through Hazmat suits, have a unsettling uniqueness.  As the men remove their protective masks in a seemingly clean zone, they start to encounter strange occurrences and feelings within the building they are searching.  It appears that they are not alone!  But are the jerky and nightmarish visions real or are they a manifestation of some sort of delirium.  The screenplay never delves too far into this question.  It's an interesting choice that plays out well as the first two men succumb to the behavior altering scenario.  But just as I was all in to this set-up, the movie shifts gears in a way inconsistent to what we have been presented with so far.  It's almost as if the movie divides into a completely separate second half.  And although it is well executed, I'd have liked there to be some acknowledgement of this shift to address the questions that arose.I liked the two individual components fine--I just didn't see the integration into one big picture.  Although billed as a grisly gore extravaganza, there is really only one scene that could be categorized as such.  Otherwise the effects are sparse and present some creepy (if familiar) looking visions.  The film succeeds in generating tension through developing a believable verbal interplay between the actors.  And the performances all worked for me!  All in all, nothing in "Bio-Dead" attempts to reinvent horror conventions.  You've undoubtedly seen many films of a similar nature within the genre, but things are tweaked here just enough to provide a different feel.  It would be interesting to see what this director could do with a bit more money.  For its limitations, this is a well constructed movie.  More creepy than aggressively scary, I'd say this one is worth a look if it sounds like your thing.  KGHarris, 7/11.
summary: Madness or Monsters?  A Haunted House Thriller Set In A Science Fiction Environment
Title: Bio-Dead

reviewText: Slow, boring, uninteresting, and leaving one wondering what is happening. I only finished it because I paid for it. Spend your hard earned dollar elsewhere.
Title: Bio-Dead
